list_definition.definition: to put (someone) on shore on a lonely island from which he cannot escape

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: The shipwrecked sailors were marooned on a desert island.

list_definition.mean_english: đẩy ai vào tình huống khó khăn
list_definition.definition: to leave (someone) in a helpless, lonely or uncomfortable position

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: I was marooned on a lonely country road.

list_ex_of_english: Moreover, in the context of large-scale migration, the differences among the maroon groups are increasingly being leveled.
Others, with the ex-chief, are marooned below the gangway.
This means that families and, as they grow older, pensioners become marooned by their less affluent state and by the decline in public transport.

The interpretation of the maroon discourses is based on consultations with local informants and about ten years of participation and observation in the community, employing a linguistic anthropological approach.
This old chart repository is an enormous, cracked-leather volume which is disappearing into maroon ash.
Another complained that nobody had ever said when the maroons would be used.
In the field it appears to be quite similar to maroon mottled siltstone except for its clayey nature.
